displayTitle: The Turing Test: An early IQ test for computers
body: Developed by Alan Turing (1912-1954) a British mathematician and the father of computer science.
instruction: Scroll through the dialogue to learn more.

_items.text: So, Alan, we just tried to distinguish between a real photo and an AI-generated one. What does that have to do with intelligence?
That's an excellent question! It gets to the heart of what Turing wondered in 1950: Can a machine be so good at imitating human intelligence that we can't tell the difference?
So, he created a test for that?

Yes, it's now known as the Turing Test. The basic idea is this: if a computer can engage in dialogue with a human without being detected as a computer, we can say it possesses a level of intelligence.
So, instead of images, it's about conversation?

Yes, in your image test, you were the judge, trying to decide if the 'output' (the image) was human-made or machine-made. The Turing Test simply expands that idea to conversation. Can a computer create conversational output that is indistinguishable from a human's?
Okay, I think I get it. So, the goal is to create a computer that can convincingly resemble human-like intelligence?

Exactly! And as AI gets more advanced, AI-generated images, text and videos will be harder and harder to identify. Of course you know that this conversation is pre-scripted, but new models like ChatGPT are so convincing, that they pass the Turing test with ease.
Thank you!

title: What is AI?
body: The Turing Test is a very helpful analogy, but Artificial Intelligence is more than just mimicking humans.

_items.title: Deal with different problems and environments
_items.body: At its core, AI seeks to create machines that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence. This includes things like understanding language, recognizing patterns, solving problems, and making decision.

_items.title: Learning and adapting
_items.body: Modern AI emphasizes enabling machines to learn from data and experience, similar to our brain. This involves writing programs that allow the AI to improve its performance over time through exposure to data and feedback.

_items.title: Autonomy
_items.body: AI aims to create intelligent systems that can operate with a degree of independence from humans. This means the AI can make decisions and take actions without explicit instructions for every situation.

title: How do machines learn?
body: Artificial intelligence is the overarching field that aims to develop intelligent machines. If we consider AI as the "brain", machine learning can be seen as the process through which the AI acquires the necessary abilities. But how do machines learn?
instruction: Use the arrows below to explore different types of machine learning.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Supervised Learning: Learning with a Teacher
_items.body:
Supervised learning is like learning with a teacher. The algorithm - the AI - is given examples with correct answers, also called labeled data.

For instance, it might be shown thousands of pictures of apples, each labeled 'apple', and pictures of bananas, labeled 'banana'. The goal is for the AI to learn the patterns so it can correctly identify apples or bananas in new, unseen pictures. Early spam filters are a common example for supervised learning.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating supervised learning with labeled data leading to a predictive model.

_items.title: Unsupervised Learning: Finding Patterns on Its Own
_items.body:
Unsupervised learning is like giving the AI system a big box of mixed-up items and asking it to sort them without telling it how. The AI looks for similarities and differences on its own to group the items. In this case, the items have no label to draw conclusions from.

The AI system might group them by color, size, or shape. This is used to discover hidden patterns or structures in data, such as customer segmentation. Recommendations on Netflix or Spotify are common examples.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating unsupervised learning finding patterns in unlabeled data.

_items.title: Deep Learning: Adding more Layers
_items.body:
Deep learning is a more advanced version that unlocks more complex tasks and higher performance. Imagine trying to teach a computer to recognize a cat in a picture. With regular machine learning, you might have to manually tell the computer what to look for – pointy ears, whiskers and a tail. Deep learning, on the other hand, learns those features automatically by detecting them throughout several layers.

Deep learning is often used for image recognition. Consider the layers in the image: In the first layer, the network might just detect edges and corners. The next layer combines those edges to form shapes. And the next layer combines the shapes to recognize cat features. Finally, the last layer puts it all together and says, 'That's a cat!

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating deep learning with a cat.

_feedback.correct: That's right! This scenario describes Supervised Learning. The AI is 'supervised' because it learns from a dataset where each example (product image) is already tagged with the correct answer or label ('defective' or 'not defective').

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite. Consider which learning type involves being explicitly told the correct answer for each piece of training data.

title: Training Data
displayTitle: Training data: The fuel for machine learning
body: Now you know what artificial intelligence is and how machines may learn from data. However, there is one major part missing: The training data. Real-world data, often produced by humans, then fed to machine learning algorithms. What are the three main considerations about training data?

back.body: The quality of the training data is crucial. If the data is noisy, incomplete, or biased, the model will learn these imperfections and perform poorly on new data.
The amount of training data is also important. More data generally leads to a more accurate model, especially for complex tasks.

The training data should be representative of the real-world data that the model will be used on. If the training data is significantly different from the real-world data, the model may not generalize well.

title: Gender Stereotypes in Image Generation
displayTitle: ...but that was just by chance, right?

body:
You don't need to be a detective to spot the pattern in the images above—they're all of white men. This happens because AI models learn from our world, and they can absorb and replicate the structural biases within their training data.

To put this to the test, I ran a simple experiment with Google's Imagen 3 model. For four different professions, I generated 30 images each using the prompts you see on the right.
Realistic photo of a ...

_items.title: of the 30 generated images exhibit male features.

_items.body: This chart reveals the hidden stereotypes a real-life language model has learned about jobs and gender. Click to learn more...

_items.title: How to Read the Chart
_items.body: Each bar shows a job's gender association. The light blue section shows the 'Male' association, and the dark blue shows the 'Female' association. Together, they always add up to 100%.

_items.title: What 'Associated With' Means
_items.body: The language model noticed that certain words often occur together. If a word often appears near 'she' or 'he', the model links them close to each other. This reflects patterns in data, not necessarily the objective truth.

_items.title: A Look at 'Nurse'
_items.body: Let's start in the middle. The language model associates 'nurse' with 'Female' 57% of the time. This shows a common stereotype that the model has learned from text.

_items.title: Now, Let's Look at 'Plumber'
_items.body: In contrast, the model associates 'plumber' with 'Male' 52% of the time. Even though it's a slight bias, the pattern consistently reflects societal stereotypes.

_items.title: An Extreme Example
_items.body: Now look at an extreme case like 'financier'. The language model shows a very strong 77% male association. In contrast, the model links 'stylist' to female with a 70% chance.

_items.title: Why This Matters
_items.body: When language models inherit these biases, they can produce unfair or skewed outcomes in real-world applications, like resume screening or content generation.

_items.title: The Takeaway
_items.body: By visualizing these biases, we can better understand them and work towards creating fairer and more responsible language models.

title: Where biases come from
displayTitle: Does that mean all AI is biased & discriminatory?
body: It's a common misconception that AI bias implies prejudice from the model itself. In this context, 'bias' simply refers to systemic patterns the AI learns and reproduces from its training data. As the previous examples show, an AI's output is a direct reflection of the information it was trained on. The results aren't intentional, they are an echo of the societal biases embedded in the source data. Ultimately, AI systems are only as good as the data they are given and the humans who build and guide them.
instruction: So where do the biases come from? Click on the panels below to learn more.

_items.front: Data was collected for other purposes

back.body: AI systems often analyze existing data that was collected for purposes different from those the AI system is pursuing. This means the data wasn't gathered with the intention of being used for, say, predictive policing or recruitment, so properties of the data that may facilitate unfair outcomes are not considered.
Historical data often reflects past societal biases and discriminatory practices. When AI systems are trained on this data, they can perpetuate and amplify these biases.

This issue arises when a machine-learning system is trained on data that does not fully represent the population that the system is meant to be applied to. AI systems can then reflect this representation bias when exposed to real-world data that differs significantly from the data they were trained on, leading to skewed or unfair outcomes.

title: Real-life impact
displayTitle: Real-life impact of biased training data
body: The previous thought experiments are mostly academic, so let's look at real examples where biases in training data led to sub-optimal and discriminatory in real-life applications.
instruction: Select the tabs to find out more.
_comment: Only set min height if you want to uniform the content container size across tab items. By default, the container will display at the height of each item's content

_items.title: Case 1: Gender Bias in Recruitment
_items.body: Amazon created an AI program to automate the shortlisting of job applicants by reviewing résumés. The tool was trained on CVs from a previous ten-year period, a dataset in which most successful applicants had been men. As a result, the AI learned to be biased against female applicants, penalizing résumés that contained phrases like "women's chess club captain." Despite attempts to correct the gender bias, Amazon ultimately abandoned the program as it did not align with the company's commitment to workplace diversity and equality (see Stahl et al. 2023).

_items.title: Case 2: AI Bias in Parole Decisions
_items.body: A prisoner named Glenn Rodríguez, who had a model rehabilitation record, applied for early release but was denied. The parole board's decision was based on a "high risk" prediction from an AI system called COMPAS. The board did not know how the AI's algorithm worked, as it was a trade secret. Rodríguez later discovered his high score was due to subjective and potentially racially prejudiced views from prison guards. Although he was eventually released, the inability to contest the AI's flawed and opaque logic meant he might have been released much sooner (see Stahl et al. 2023).

_items.title: Case 3: Bias in Facial Recognition
_items.body: An engineering student of Asian descent in New Zealand had his passport photo rejected by an automated system because it incorrectly claimed his eyes were closed. This incident points to a wider problem of ethnicity-based errors in facial recognition technology. Similar systems have shown bias against other groups; for instance, photos of dark-skinned women in the UK were four times more likely to be graded as poor quality, with one black student's photo being rejected because the system inaccurately detected her mouth was open (see Stahl et al. 2023).

title: AI Solutions
body: While previous discussions may have highlighted the more concerning aspects of AI and machine learning, this section explores the proactive solutions and advancements that are effectively addressing these issues.
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Stay critical
_items.body:
You may have noticed that this course intentionally uses materials from different AI models, such as Google's Imagen 3 and 4 for images and an older language model for the gender bias chart. This is by design.

These choices demonstrate key points in the history of machine learning and serve as a reminder to remain critical of two things: the output of AI systems in sensitive applications and, just as importantly, the motivations of the organizations that provide them.

When implementing any sort of AI system, it is helpful to keep the examples above in mind to avoid unwanted outcomes.

_graphic.attribution: Lil Artsy on www.pexels.com

_items.title: Guardrails
_items.body:
The previous examples highlighted how flawed training data can lead to biased or harmful outcomes, a concern for developers and regulators alike. In response, model creators implement safety filters and 'guardrails' to prevent unwanted behavior.

These guardrails can range from output moderation and bias mitigation to mechanisms that ensure responses align with societal norms or a specific corporate identity.

To ensure the line between acceptable and unacceptable behavior isn't drawn solely by large tech companies, initiatives like Guardrails.AI provide open-source, community-driven standards for AI models.

_items.title: New models do much better
_items.body:
Modern AI models tend to exhibit a reduction in bias, which can be attributed to two main factors: the implementation of explicit guardrails and a more sophisticated linguistic comprehension that moves beyond the simplified gender-role correlations of previous models.

For example, the language embeddings integral to ChatGPT yield significantly more equitable associations between gender and professions in contrast to the chart above.

Likewise, Google's Imagen 4 demonstrates this advancement by producing greater demographic variety; a prompt for a 'realistic photo of a nurse' results in images that feature men and women in approximately equal measure. Consider the image on the left.

title: Copyright in general
body: Copyright is a legal right granting creators exclusive control over their original literary and artistic works. As part of Intellectual Property (IP) law, it safeguards 'works of authorship' by empowering creators to manage how their creations are used and distributed.
instruction: Click on the panels below to learn more about copyright.

back.body: Copyright protects the concrete expression of an idea, not the idea itself. It applies to tangible literary and artistic works like novels, songs, paintings, and software, giving creators control over their specific manifestations.

To be copyrighted, a work must be expressed in a concrete way (not abstract ideas) and be original. Originality means it's an intellectual creation by a human author, reflecting their personality and creative choices. This human authorship is fundamental, especially in German and EU law.

_items.front: What are the rights of the owner?

back.body: Owners gain exclusive rights to reproduce, distribute, and publicly communicate their work. They also hold moral rights, including disclosure, integrity, and attribution, ensuring control. Copyright generally lasts for the author's lifetime plus 70 years in EU Member States.

title: Copyright and AI
displayTitle: And why is this important for AI?
body: Recall the Turing Test from the first part of this course: The output of AI systems has gotten so good, that much of is is hard to distinguish from human content. And much of the human content out there on the internet is protected by copyright laws. In this lesson, we will address three questions:

_items.title: Does the training of AI violate copyright law?
Can the output of AI systems infringe copyright work?

title: AI training and copyright
displayTitle: AI training might violate copyright law
body: The question of whether training AI models on copyrighted material constitutes infringement is a central and highly debated legal issue. It involves complex interpretations of existing copyright laws and the emergence of new regulations, particularly in the EU. Understanding this area requires examining both the technical nature of AI models and the legal frameworks governing data use.
instruction: Click on the panels below to learn more about this complex issue.

_items.title: Models do not store copyright data
_items.body: AI models typically do not store exact copies of copyrighted works. Instead, they learn by extracting and encoding abstract concepts into numerical representations. This process of decomposition and abstraction means the trained model itself is not a direct copy, and thus typically does not violate copyright.

_items.title: During training, this is an ongoing debate
_items.body: AI models are trained on vast amounts of data, often including copyrighted materials scraped from the internet. Using this data without explicit authorization can be considered copyright infringement. In the US, proponents often argue this falls under 'fair use.' In Germany and the EU, specific 'Text and Data Mining' (TDM) exceptions exist, which allow TDM under certain conditions like scientific research.

title: Ongoing copyright cases
body: Let's explore key ongoing court cases that are shaping the intersection of AI training and copyright law.
instruction: Select the tabs to find out more.
_comment: Only set min height if you want to uniform the content container size across tab items. By default, the container will display at the height of each item's content

_items.title: NYT vs. OpenAI & Microsoft
_items.body: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft, alleging that OpenAI copied millions of its articles without permission or payment to train its large language models. OpenAI's defense relies on the fair use doctrine. A federal judge recently allowed the main copyright infringement claims to proceed, rejecting OpenAI's dismissal request. This high-profile case is crucial for defining the relationship between generative AI and copyright law.

_items.title: Getty Images vs. Stability AI
_items.body: Getty Images sued Stability AI, creator of the Stable Diffusion text-to-image AI model. Getty alleges Stability AI used millions of its copyrighted images without permission to train its model. The lawsuit claims copyright and trademark infringement, noting the AI sometimes reproduces Getty's watermarks or visually similar content.

_items.title: Kneschke vs. LAION
_items.body: Artist Christopher Kneschke (and others in a related class-action suit) sued LAION, a non-profit that compiles vast image-text datasets from the internet. These datasets are used to train large AI models. The lawsuit alleges LAION's datasets include copyrighted images without artists' consent, thereby facilitating copyright infringement by models trained on them.

title: Infringement by AI Output
displayTitle: Yes, AI output can infringe copyrights
body: Even if an AI model is trained legally, the content it generates can still lead to copyright infringement. This occurs when the AI's output is too similar to an existing copyrighted work, infringing upon the rights of the original creator.
instruction: Use the arrows below to explore the ways AI-generated content can infringe copyright.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Substantial Similarity
_items.body: If AI-generated content (like an image, text, or music) is so close to an existing copyrighted work that an average person would recognize it as copied, it can be deemed infringing. This means the AI output has captured enough of the original's creative elements to cross a legal threshold.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating supervised learning with labeled data leading to a predictive model.

_items.title: Unauthorized Derivative Works
_items.body: Copyright holders have the exclusive right to create 'derivative works'—new works based on their original creations. If a user prompts an AI to generate content that clearly builds upon a copyrighted character, setting, or specific artistic style without permission (e.g., a new story featuring a famous cartoon character), the AI's output could be considered an unauthorized derivative work.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating supervised learning with labeled data leading to a predictive model.

_items.title: The Snoopy Problem
_items.body: This highlights how AI can 'memorize' elements from its training data and then reproduce them in its output. The more distinctive and frequently represented a character or visual identifier is in the training data, the more likely the AI is to reproduce it when prompted. For example, AI can generate highly similar depictions of well-known characters like Snoopy or Mickey Mouse, or reproduce distinctive artistic styles. This happens because the AI learns consistent characteristics, making it easy to evoke an infringing output, even if it's not an exact copy of a single original work.

_graphic.alt: Diagram illustrating supervised learning with labeled data leading to a predictive model.

title: AI output is not copyrightable
displayTitle: No, AI results are not directly copyrightable
body: The current understanding and framework of copyright law generally do not permit the copyrighting of output directly by AI models, because AI systems themselves cannot be considered authors or legal entities.
instruction: Click on the panels below to explore the nuances of copyright for content created with AI.

back.body: Copyright law fundamentally requires a human author. This involves a 'personal stamp' and 'free, deliberate choices' reflecting human personality and creativity. AI systems, lacking legal entity status, cannot express personality or hold rights, thus disqualifying them as authors.

_items.front: AI as a tool, not an author

back.body: While AI can produce works that could be protected, copyright depends on sufficient human intervention. Humans programming, training, modifying, or selecting AI output may claim copyright, as the AI is considered a tool, like a paintbrush or word processor.

If human input is 'insufficient' in 'free and creative choices', AI-generated content may lack the necessary 'authorship' for copyright. Protection hinges entirely on the degree and nature of human creative input involved.

title: Key Recommendations
body: To conclude this module, here are three key recommendations for navigating the complex landscape of copyright law and Artificial Intelligence:

_items.title: Do not upload any copyright-protected information
_items.body: Make sure that you own the right of any material you supply to any AI system for training or context-enhancement.

_items.title: Diligently review all AI-generated outputs for potential infringement
_items.body: Scrutinize AI-generated content for resemblances to existing copyrighted works and perform due diligence before publishing or commercializing it, as AI outputs can infringe copyright.

_items.title: Ensure sufficient human creative input for copyright protection of AI-assisted works
_items.body: To secure copyright for AI-assisted works, ensure significant human intervention, creative direction, or modification of the AI's output, as AI alone cannot be an author.

_items.title: If in doubt, involve legal experts
_items.body: If you are not sure whether your new content violates copyright law, always involve legal experts, e.g. your company's legal team.

title: Quiz: Copyright Checklist
displayTitle: To do’s before releasing AI-assisted work
body: You have used an AI tool to assist in the creation of a new product (e.g., generating design elements, marketing text, or part of a software code). Before publicly releasing this product, what crucial checks should you perform to address copyright concerns, according to the recommendations in this module? (Select all that apply)
instruction: Choose one or more options which applies, then select Submit.
ariaQuestion: What crucial checks should you perform before releasing AI-assisted work?

_items.text: Verify that any information you supplied to the AI system for training or context-enhancement was copyright-free or that you had the necessary rights to use it.
Diligently review all AI-generated outputs incorporated into the product for any potential resemblances to existing copyrighted works.
_items.altText: Option: Review AI output for infringement.

_items.text: Ensure that there was sufficient human creative input in the final product to establish human authorship for copyright protection.
Check if the AI model itself has been registered for copyright protection with the relevant authorities.
_items.altText: Option: Check AI model copyright registration.

_feedback.title: Copyright Checklist Explanation
_feedback.altTitle: Feedback on your answer about AI product release.
_feedback.correct: Excellent! All three points (A, B, and C) are critical steps from the module's recommendations. Ensuring your input data is clear, scrutinizing AI-generated output for potential infringement, and maintaining sufficient human creative control are essential for navigating copyright law with AI-assisted products.

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite. Review the 'Key Recommendations' section. Remember, copyright concerns apply to both the input to the AI and its generated output, as well as the overall human contribution.
_incorrect.final: The correct answers are A, B, and C. The recommendations highlight the importance of: 1) ensuring you have the rights to any data you provide to the AI; 2) diligently checking AI-generated content for resemblances to existing copyrighted works; and 3) making sure there's enough human creative input to claim copyright on the final work. The copyright of the AI model itself is not a primary concern for product release checks by a user.

_partlyCorrect.final: You've identified some crucial steps, but not all of them. The correct answers are A, B, and C. The recommendations highlight the importance of: 1) ensuring you have the rights to any data you provide to the AI; 2) diligently checking AI-generated content for resemblances to existing copyrighted works; and 3) making sure there's enough human creative input to claim copyright on the final work. The copyright of the AI model itself is not a primary concern for product release checks by a user.

title: Key GDPR Definitions
body: Before examining the application of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) to AI, it is necessary to understand its fundamental terminology. The GDPR establishes its regulatory framework through precise definitions. The following three concepts are central to discussions about AI:
instruction: Explore each term below to understand its meaning.

back.body: Personal data refers to any information that can identify a living person, either directly or indirectly. Examples include names, identification numbers, location data, or any data that can be used to ascertain an individual's identity.

Data processing means any action performed on personal data. This includes collecting it, storing it, using it, sharing it, changing it, or even deleting it. Such processing can be carried out manually or through automated systems.
Consent means clear, voluntary, specific, and informed permission from an individual for their personal data to be used. It requires an unambiguous affirmative action and cannot be implied.

title: How AI processes personal data
body: Artificial Intelligence systems heavily rely on data for their functionality. Understanding how personal data is handled at different stages of AI development and deployment is crucial for navigating GDPR compliance. Select the tabs to explore each stage.
instruction: Select the tabs to learn more.

_items.title: Stage 1: Data Collection & Initial Training
_items.body: AI systems are built on an 'enormous appetite for data'. This initial stage involves collecting vast quantities of data to train algorithms to detect patterns and make predictions. If the data is sufficiently granular, it can allow re-identification of individuals, meaning personal data is involved from the very outset. This accumulation of relevant data is a key factor for AI-related issues, as it is often used to create personality profiles or for individualized services.

_items.title: Stage 2: AI Model Development & Data Leakage
_items.body: During the development phase, AI models are created from the collected training data. Even after a model is trained, it might inadvertently 'leak' some of the personal data it was trained on through methods like model inversion or membership inference attacks. This means the trained model itself can contain personal information, and its sharing or transfer to third parties is considered 'processing' under GDPR, regardless of whether the original data was raw or pseudonymized.

_items.title: Stage 3: AI Applications
_items.body: The final stage involves deploying the trained AI model to make real-world predictions and decisions. This 'inference stage' processes personal data to derive new information, for example, a bank using an AI to predict loan default risk. This application of AI to personal data constitutes 'further processing' and must adhere to GDPR principles, as it directly impacts individuals through automated decisions and recommendations.

title: Frictions between AI and GDPR
body: When companies use Artificial Intelligence, it often relies on your personal information. While the GDPR aims to protect you, AI's unique characteristics can create specific challenges for individuals interacting with these systems within a company.
instruction: Click on the panels below to learn more.

_items.title: Purpose limitation
_items.body: AI systems often use your information in ways that weren't initially explained or agreed upon.

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body: Decisions made by AI can be hard to understand. It's difficult for a company to explain why an AI reached a particular conclusion about you, making it challenging to know how its decisions are reached.

_items.title: Data minimization and storage limitation
_items.body: AI thrives on large amounts of data, which often means more of your information is collected than strictly necessary. This also makes it difficult to know when or if your data will ever be deleted.

_items.title: Accuracy
_items.body: Data must be accurate and up-to-date. However, AI's 'black box' nature makes it challenging to detect and correct inaccurate information. A key nuance is that while input data must be accurate, AI's outputs are often probabilistic prognoses, which complicates the application of this principle.

title: Key recommendations
body: As an end-user, your actions can significantly impact data protection within company AI systems. Here's what you need to know:
instruction: Explore these recommendations to understand how to protect personal data.

back.body: As an end-user, never input personal data belonging to others into an AI system without confirming a clear, explicit legal basis, such as their specific and informed consent.

If your role involves handling or inputting data that contributes to AI systems, prioritize using anonymization or pseudonymization techniques to remove or obscure personal identifiers. These methods are vital for reducing the risk of re-identification and align with the principle of data minimization.

As an individual providing your own data, carefully scrutinize requests for your consent, especially if they are vague, implicit, or presented as a default opt-out. GDPR requires consent to be 'freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous,' highlighting that broad or implied agreements often fall short.

title: Introduction to the EU AI Act
body: Before we start with the major regulatory requirements, let's start with a brief introduction of the EU AI Act.
instruction: Click on the panels below to explore the fundamental questions about the EU AI Act.

back.body: The EU AI Act aims to ensure AI development and use are safe, trustworthy, and respect fundamental rights. It seeks to balance innovation with citizen protection, building trust in AI.

Any machine-based system placed on the EU market operating with varying autonomy and potential adaptiveness that infers from input to generate virtual or physical outputs (predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions).
The EU AI Act impacts a wide range of entities and individuals, each with specific roles and responsibilities in ensuring compliance and responsibility. We will discuss the roles in more detail next.

title: The EU AI Act: Key Milestones
body: Now that the now the why, the what and the who, the remaining quesiton is: 'When?'
instruction: Swipe or click to view the timeline of the most important milestones.

_items.title: February 2025
_items.body: The strictest rules come into play, banning certain AI systems with unacceptable risks, such as social scoring by public authorities and real-time remote biometric identification in public spaces.

_items.title: August 2025
_items.body: Rules for General Purpose AI (GPAI) models, which are broad AI systems like large language models, become active. Additionally, member states must have set up their national authorities to enforce the Act and established penalties for non-compliance.

_items.title: August  2026
_items.body: The majority of the AI Act's provisions begin to apply. This includes requirements for high-risk AI systems.

_items.title: August 2027
_items.body: Specific obligations for all new high-risk AI systems (like those used in critical infrastructure or medical devices) come into full effect. Also, providers of GPAI models that were introduced before August 2025 must be fully compliant by this date.

title: Copyright and AI
body: As stated above, the AI affects a broad range of individuals and authorities. The regulatory responsibilities depend on two main questions:

_items.title: What is the risk of the AI system?

title: Key Roles in the EU AI Act Ecosystem
body: Article 3 (2-8) of the AI Act defines several key roles, each with specific responsibilities related to AI systems and general-purpose AI models. Understanding these roles is crucial for navigating compliance.
instruction: Click on each panel to learn more about each key role.

back.body: This is the company or person who creates an AI system or a general-purpose AI model (or has it made for them) and then sells it or makes it available for others to use, under their own brand, whether it's paid or free.

This is anyone (a person, company, or government body) who uses an AI system for their own operations or services. This doesn't include people using AI for purely personal, non-work-related activities.

A Distributor is a business or person in the supply chain (like a reseller) who makes an AI system available for sale in the EU, but they aren't the original creator. If the system is brought in from outside the EU, the business or person acts as an Importer.

title: Target audience
body: To maintain the status of Deployer, avoid rebranding the AI system you plan on using. Also, make sure to use the system only for the purpose it is originally intended for. If you are unsure about your role, use the EU AI Act Compliance Checker which is linked in the sources at the end of this lesson.

_graphic.attribution: Erwan Hesry on www.unsplash.com

_items.title: Harmful Manipulation
_items.body: AI systems that use subliminal, manipulative, or deceptive techniques with the objective or effect of distorting behavior, causing or likely to cause significant harm.

_items.title: Exploitation of Vulnerabilities
_items.body: AI systems that take advantage of vulnerabilities related to age, disability, or specific social/economic situations, with the objective or effect of distorting behavior, causing or likely to cause significant harm.

_items.title: Social Scoring
_items.body: Systems that evaluate or classify individuals based on their social behavior, leading to detrimental or unfavorable treatment in social contexts unrelated to the original data collection, or that is unjustified or disproportionate.

_items.title: Predictive Policing
_items.body: AI systems designed to predict a person's risk of committing a criminal offense.

_items.title: Untargeted Scraping for Facial Recognition
_items.body: Untargeted scraping of the internet or CCTV material for the purpose of creating or expanding facial recognition databases.

_items.title: Emotion Recognition in Specific Contexts
_items.body: AI systems used for inferring emotions in workplaces and educational institutions.

_items.title: Biometric Categorisation of Protected Characteristics
_items.body: Biometric categorisation used to deduce certain protected characteristics (e.g., political opinions, sexual orientation, race, religious beliefs).

_items.title: Real-time Remote Biometric ID
_items.body: Real-time remote biometric identification for law enforcement purposes in publicly accessible spaces (with limited, strict exceptions for serious crimes).

_items.title: Safety Components of Products
_items.body: AI systems used as safety components in products already subject to EU safety regulations (e.g., medical devices, aviation, cars).

_items.title: Biometric Identification Systems
_items.body: AI used for remote biometric identification of natural persons (excluding real-time use by law enforcement in public, which is generally prohibited).

_items.title: Critical Infrastructure Management
_items.body: AI systems acting as safety components in managing essential services like water, gas, electricity, or traffic control.

_items.title: Education & Vocational Training
_items.body: AI used for determining access to educational institutions, assigning individuals, or assessing learning outcomes (e.g., scoring exams).

_items.title: Employment & Worker Management
_items.body: AI systems used for recruitment, applicant screening, evaluation of candidates, task allocation, monitoring, or performance evaluation of workers.

_items.title: Access to Essential Services
_items.body: AI used for evaluating creditworthiness, dispatching emergency services, or assessing eligibility for public assistance benefits (e.g., welfare, healthcare).

_items.title: Law Enforcement Applications
_items.body: AI systems used by law enforcement for purposes such as assessing crime risk, polygraphs, or evaluating the reliability of evidence.

_items.title: Migration, Asylum & Border Control
_items.body: AI systems used to assess eligibility for asylum, visa, or residence permits, or for verifying travel document authenticity.

_items.title: Administration of Justice & Democracy
_items.body: AI systems intended to assist judicial authorities or to influence the outcome of elections or referendums.

title: Legal requirements for high-risk systems
body: Before implementing a high-risk system, for example an automated resumé screening in recruiting, make sure to address the following legal requirements.
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Governance and data management
_items.body: Deployers must ensure the AI system is used according to instructions. If they control input data, it must be relevant and sufficiently representative for the system's intended use. Applicable Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) must be carried out, and registration in the EU database is required if specified.

_items.title: Transparency and notification
_items.body: Before using or putting high-risk AI systems into service in the workplace, deployers must inform affected workers and their representatives. Additionally, natural persons must be informed of the use of high-risk AI in decisions to which they are subject.

_items.title: Risk management and human oversight
_items.body: Deployers are required to monitor the high-risk AI system and the level of risk it poses. They must promptly inform the provider, distributor, and relevant market surveillance authority if the use may result in risk to health and safety or fundamental rights, and suspend use of the system in such cases. Human oversight must be ensured by individuals with the necessary training and support. Deployers must also keep automatically generated logs of system use (where under their control) for a minimum of six months and cooperate with relevant competent authorities.

_items.title: Right to an explanation
_items.body: Upon an individual's request, deployers must provide a detailed explanation of the role of AI in any decision-making process that has a legal or similarly significant effect on that individual, particularly if it has an adverse impact on their health and safety or fundamental rights. The explanation must also set out the main elements of the decision.

title: Quiz: Understanding EU AI Act Roles
body: Company JellyF!sh, an EU-based enterprise, integrates an AI-powered customer sentiment analysis tool, developed by a third-party vendor, into its internal customer support operations to better understand customer feedback.
instruction: Choose the one option that best describes Company X's primary role.
ariaQuestion: What primary role does Company X assume by using this AI tool?

_items.text: Provider
Deployer
Distributor
Importer

_feedback.title: Understanding Roles in the EU AI Act
_feedback.altTitle: Feedback on your answer about EU AI Act roles.
_feedback.correct: That's correct! Company X is acting as a **Deployer** because it is using the AI system for its own operations and services, rather than creating, selling, or importing it for commercial distribution.

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite. Revisit the 'Key Roles in the EU AI Act Ecosystem' section. Consider whether Company X is creating, selling, or simply using the AI tool.
_incorrect.final: The correct answer is **Deployer**. A Provider creates or makes an AI system available under their own brand. A Distributor makes an AI system available for sale without being the original creator. An Importer brings a system from outside the EU for sale within the EU. Company X is simply *using* the AI tool for its own internal business purposes, which defines the Deployer role.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: This question has only one correct answer. Please re-evaluate your choice based on the content.
_partlyCorrect.final: This question has only one correct answer. The correct answer is **Deployer**, as Company X is using the AI system for its own operations.
